newsitem.title: ITALY: Top Sicilian Mafia bosses tried for 1993 bombings.
newsitem.headline: Top Sicilian Mafia bosses tried for 1993 bombings.

text.p: Mafia bosses Salvatore Riina, Leoluca Bagarella and Giovanni Brusca went on trial on Tuesday for a string of bombings that rocked Rome, Florence and Milan in 1993, judicial sources said.

Mafia "Godfather" Riina and his brother-in-law Bagarella were among twelve of 28 defendents who were at Florence's Santa Verdiana courthouse for the trial's opening while Brusca did not attend, the sources said.
The three jailed bosses are suspected along with wanted mob leader Bernardo Provenzano of masterminding the bombings, which killed 10 people and damaged several cultural sites.
One wing of Florence's Uffizi Gallery has only recently reopened following the May 1993 car bomb attack which wrecked parts of its priceless Renaissance art collection.

Florentine magistrates have said they believe the Mafia carried out two blasts against Rome churches during the same campaign to punish Pope John Paul for a strong attack he made against the Mafia during a visit to Sicily the same year.
Meanwhile, police on Tuesday arrested four more suspects in the 1992 killing of leading anti-Mafia judge Paolo Borsellino and magistrates told 24 jailed Mafiosi they too were suspected.
The 24 included Riina, Brusca and top boss Benedetto "Nitto" Santapaola, who is also in prison.
Magistrates told a news conference in the Sicilian town of Caltanisetta the arrests and warrants were part of a probe into the car bomb killing of Borsellino and five bodyguards in July 1992.

Borsellino was killed two months after fellow anti-Mafia judge Giovanni Falcone was blown up along with his wife and three bodyguards by a bomb planted under a highway outside the Sicilian capital, Palermo.
Brusca, one of the mob's most ferocious members, is also accused of setting off the bomb which killed Falcone.
A first trial for the Borsellino bombing ended in January with the conviction of four lower level Mafiosi accused of carrying out the killing.
A second trial began last month with 18 defendants including boss of bosses Riina, who was arrested in 1993.
The four men arrested on Tuesday were suspected low level Mafiosi.
One, Giuseppe Biondo, was suspected of preparing the remote control device which set off the car bomb. The other three were suspected of having provided shelter for Mafiosi.
